item.title: Cyberpunk 2077: Best Early OP Builds To Try
item.description:
Summary

  • Prioritize Intelligence and Cool for a powerful Stealth Netrunner Build.
  • Reflexes and Body essential for becoming a Cyber-Samurai with a Katana.
  • Balance Reflexes, Body, and Intelligence for an adaptable All-Rounder build.

Despite having a bit of a rocky start, Cyberpunk 2077 has shaped up to be one of CD Projekt Red's finest games with surprisingly massive concurrent player counts, even today. One of the many improvements that paved the way for this rebound is the much more complex and interesting RPG systems.

Yet, sometimes players can find it difficult to get off the starting blocks in Cyberpunk 2077, particularly on punishing difficulties that make some builds unworkable. These are four great builds that are designed to set a strong foundation for any player, using accessible weapons, and all are designed to be for players below level 10.

4 Stealth Netrunner Build

A Cyborg Ghost In The System

  • Prioritize Intelligence and Cool attributes, with some in Technical Ability.
  • All about avoiding combat and using cyberdecks for maximum impact.

In the world of Cyberpunk 2077 fans who prioritize build quality, the stealth netrunner build is a little bit infamous for not just being powerful, but absurdly powerful. In fact, with the right combination of perks, attributes, cyberdecks, quickhacks, and cyberware, players can become near-unstoppable in the late game.

The early game is a different story. While the stealth netrunner is still more than viable, players tend to be limited by a more constrained selection of quickhacks and cyberdecks. However, that's no barrier to excellence.

When creating your character, prioritize putting points into the Intelligence and Cool attributes. These are your core drivers for quickhack aptitude as well as stealth skills. For whatever's left over, make sure to put at least one point into Body (to get the slow health regen) and some more into Technical Ability to improve cyberware capabilities.

Then, whenever possible, check out cyberdeck stores and pick up whatever Quickhacks possible. At this point in the game, Short Circuit and Overheat are going to be the workhorses in a netrunner's arsenal, but Ping is also very useful for maintaining stealth, and Weapon Glitch can save a player in a bind. These quickhacks are a solid foundation that lead up to some of the best in the game.

Make sure to prioritize abilities in the early stages that increase critical hit rate and damage for headshots, and also any abilities that increase RAM, RAM regen, or the amount of quickhacks and their efficacy.

3 Katana Build

A Cyber-Samurai

  • Prioritize Reflexes, Body, and a little bit of Technical Ability.
  • This is all about wielding a katana and becoming a menace in melee.

In a world full of guns, chooms who run with a katana as their weapon are either suicidal or extremely confident; this build is about becoming part of the latter category. Though it might seem counterintuitive, a katana build can be one of the most effective damage dealers in the whole game, but it can be tough in the early game, particularly on harder difficulties.

First things first, put a good amount of points into Reflexes (which will unlock lots of blade-related perks for later) as well as Body (which is essential for an HP boost to tank some hits). These two attributes will drive everything else, but if damage is still proving too high in the early game, consider investing more points into Body to get more HP to work with.

Next, consider the Parkour! perk for faster vaulting (to get to enemies faster) and Dash, which is absolutely essential for mid-fight mobility. Painkiller, Dorph-Head, and Comeback Kid are all great Body perks that are worth considering, too. With mobility and the ability to tank some hits, a cyber-samurai can get in close and strike.

In the early game, there aren't too many iconic or legendary melee weapons to work with, and choices are limited. Always keep an eye out for katanas that complement the build style, and save up those hard-earned Eddies for a trip to the weapons shop. Their prices may be extortionate, but in the early game, extra points of damage can be worth the hit to the wallet.

2 The All-Rounder

A Choom For All Seasons

  • A nice mix of Reflexes, Body, and Intelligence.
  • This is a build about keeping options open and being ready for any situation.

It may not be the flashiest option, but in the early game, there's very little harm in being a prominent all-rounder, able to tackle any situation as it arises. For some players, it's often too early to commit to a build at this stage, so the all-rounder gives a nice taste of everything the game has to offer, so no choice needs to be made immediately.

Begin with a nice mix of Reflexes (which will help with gunplay), Body (which will help with a bigger HP pool), and Intelligence (which will lay the foundation for quickhacks). With a gun, some health to play with, and the ability to do some hacking, players can take advantage of all of Cyberpunk 's central gameplay systems without overly committing to one or the other.

A great Quickhack for the early stages is Short Circuit. It's a low-cost hack that does a set bit of damage to an enemy and momentarily stuns them, laying them up for a hail of bullets from whichever gun you prefer to use. Similarly, Overheat does good damage over time, which helps chip away at the bigger health pools of more fearsome foes.

As an all-rounder, it's worth taking a hefty arsenal into any fight, so there's no situation where the player is outgunned. An all-purpose assault rifle for general firefights, an SMG for when things get close up, and a great sniper rifle for gunfights at long-range means this build is never at a disadvantage. It may be the master of none, but in the early game, who needs to be a master?

1 Gunslinger

The Black Hat Cowboy

  • Focus on putting attributes into Cool, Technical Ability, and Reflexes.
  • This is all about being a pro with the guns, popping off headshots, and being the meanest cyber-cowboy around.

There's maybe nothing more contradictory to the entire aesthetic of Cyberpunk 2077 than being a gunslinging cowboy, but it's genuinely one of the most fun ways to play the game, and there's plenty of great build ideas to make it happen, even in the early game.

Eventually, players will be able to get perks like Deadeye and High Noon in the Cool attribute that lean hard into a gunslinging player aiming for headshots from a distance, but that's not viable in the early game. However, several early Cool perks lay key foundations for that build. For example, Focus is a key mechanic in the Cool tree, unlockable around level 9, that buffs headshot damage, weak spot damage, removes stamina cost for shooting, and allows for more accurate shots. It's all about aiming well and making every shot count.

However, in the early game, it's worth thinking about other attributes too. For example, in Reflexes, Muscle Memory allows players to reload while sprinting, which is key for a player using a revolver, which needs to be reloaded a lot. Similarly, the baseline Body perks get HP regen on the go, and early Technical Ability perks like Glutton For War help keep the HP item economy flowing in the heat of battle.

Though a revolver is likely the main weapon, it's also worth taking along a shotgun for any enemy that wants to get up closer. Again, in the early game, it's unlikely a player is going to find any crazy weapons or unique pistols, but look for revolvers, pistols, and shotguns to get a feel for how they handle and aim. By the time the late game comes around, the better the player is at accuracy, the more effective this build will be.

6 Images
6 Images

Your comment has not been saved

Follow
Followed
Cyberpunk 2077
RPG
Action
Systems
6 /10
100
8.9 /10
OpenCritic Reviews
Top Critic Avg: 76 /100 Critics Rec: 65%
Released
December 10, 2020
ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Nudity, Strong Language, Strong Sexual Content, Use of Drugs and Alcohol
Developer(s)
CD Projekt Red

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

Cyberpunk 2077 is an open-world action-adventure from the creators of The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt, CD Projekt Red.

Set in Night City, a megalopolis obsessed with power, glamour and body modification, you play as V, a mercenary outlaw going after a one-of-a-kind implant that is the key to immortality.

Upgraded with next-gen in mind and featuring free additional content, customize your character and playstyle as you take on jobs, build a reputation, and unlock upgrades.

The relationships you forge and the choices you make will shape the story and the world around you. Legends are made here. What will yours be?

Powered by

item.title: Monopoly GO: How to Get Fantastic Four Collectibles
item.description:
The Monopoly GO x Fantastic Four collaboration is the perfect way to celebrate the return of Marvel’s first family to the spotlight. Starting on July 13, 2025 , this limited-time event lets players participate in action-packed minigames and collect exclusive cosmetic items, inspired by The Fantastic Four.

This collab arrives just in time to build excitement for Marvel Studios’ The Fantastic Four: First Steps , which hits cinemas on July 25, 2025. This guide breaks down all the ways you can collect these limited-time Marvel items and bring a bit of heroic action to your next Monopoly GO run.

Play Minigames

Monopoly GO 's Fantastic Four crossover event brings a ton of themed minigames. These minigames are the best way to get your hands on these heroic collectibles. Make sure to keep an eye out for these minigames:

Fantastic Racers

The Fantastic Racers is an iteration of the Tycoon Racers minigame where players compete against other Tycoons to climb the leaderboards and claim victory. If you secure first place in this minigame, you’ll win the Human Torch Token , and a vault that could hold a Wild Sticker or a Swap Pack.

Fantastic Partners

Like regular Partner Events, the Fantastic Partners event challenges you to team up with your most active friends to build landmarks on your board. Completing all builds in the Fantastic Partners event is how you'll win The Thing Token, along with Fantastic Four-themed Emojis and either a Wild Sticker or Swap Pack.

Fantastic Treasures

The Fantastic Treasures minigame takes you on an adventure across the galactic city. Here, you’ll have to dig up secret items inspired by The Fantastic Four universe. Finding all the hidden artifacts in this dig event rewards you with the exclusive Mister Fantastic Token.

Peg-E Deluxe Drop

The Fantastic Four collaboration with Monopoly GO also brings a unique Deluxe Drop minigame. It’s the same as the Peg-E Prize Drop, with a special twist. Instead of just standard rewards, you'll find Fantastic Four-themed items like the Invisible Woman Token , along with exclusive emojis, shields, and dice skins.

The release dates and details for all minigames mentioned here are subject to change by Scopely at any time. Make sure to keep an eye on the official Monopoly GO social media platforms for event announcements.

Participate in Community Events & Challenges

Just like the Star Wars-themed Community Challenges, it’s possible that Scopely will host community events centered around The Fantastic Four. These large-scale activities take place on the Discord channel and involve teaming up with other players globally to hit shared goals, like landing on certain tiles, completing builds, or hitting milestone scores.

As you contribute to the event, you’ll win rewards which may include Fantastic Four collectibles. The more active you are, the better your chances of grabbing those rare, limited-time items.

Claim All Free Goodies

Keep an eye on Monopoly GO 's official social media channels and community groups, especially on Discord and Facebook. They often release free dice links and give away unexpected gifts or freebies, including Fantastic Four collectibles. Don't forget to check your email for a newsletter from Mr. M that might contain reward links, too.

Your comment has not been saved

item.title: 8 Game Mechanics Every Good Open-World Game Should Have
item.description:
Summary

  • Fun traversal mechanics, like swinging in Marvel's Spider-Man 2, keep open-world games engaging.
  • Side quests in games like Red Dead Redemption 2 should be diverse distractions, not mere tasks.
  • Open-world games benefit from boundaries and meaningful progression, seen in titles like Gothic and Kingdom Come: Deliverance.

Open-world games continue to dominate the industry, drawing players in for hundreds of hours and prompting major publishers to invest heavily in studios that specialize in them. Despite their long-standing popularity, there is also growing fatigue among gamers when it comes to exploring yet another sprawling map.

This weariness often stems from market saturation, but every so often, a standout title reignites the community's excitement. These gems point to a core truth about the open-world game: while the genre is vast with wide room for experimentation, certain game mechanics are essential to making an open-world experience feel fresh, immersive, and worth the time investment.

8 Fun Traversal - Marvel's Spider-Man 2

Travel Should Be Fun, Not A Chore

8 Images
8 Images
Marvel's Spider-Man 2
9 /10
48
8.9 /10
Released
October 20, 2023

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T For Teen Due To Blood, Drug Reference, Mild Language, Violence
Powered by

One of the fastest ways for an open-world game to feel stale is by making players trudge across miles of terrain with little to no excitement. While walking or sprinting might make sense early on as they get to know the environment, especially for games with massive maps, it can become a drag by the mid or late game if the game doesn’t offer more engaging ways to get from A to B.

Fast travel is one way to do it, but a loading screen isn't exactly the most compelling gameplay. Marvel’s Spider-Man 2 is a textbook example: swinging through New York City never gets old, and it’s so fluid and fun that many players happily ignore fast travel altogether. Other games have followed suit with gliders, mounts, jetpacks, wall-running, and other supercharged traversal mechanics that double as toys, not just tools.

7 Side Quests With Gameplay Variety - Red Dead Redemption 2

Distractions Are The Main Event

8 Images
8 Images
Marvel's Spider-Man 2
9 /10
48
8.9 /10
Released
October 20, 2023

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T For Teen Due To Blood, Drug Reference, Mild Language, Violence
Powered by

The fantasy that drives the appeal of an open world is that there might be something interesting off the beaten path. Side quests shouldn't just be homework for the main gameplay loop. They should be distractions and temptations that give players the impression that there is a living world of possibility apart from them, always out there on the periphery waiting to be discovered; something that Red Dead Redemption 2 excels at.

One moment, Arthur might be hunting legendary animals, the next he's helping a stranger with a bizarre personal problem, or fishing in the quiet of a foggy morning. Each layer (minigame, crafting, or lore-delving) should harmonize with the main gameplay loop. Great side-quests should be enticing enough to create a push-pull tension with the side shows, compelling players to keep pushing forward.

6 Inticing Boundaries And Constraining Consequences - Gothic

Defying Barriers And Overcoming Limitations Can Be A Strong Motivator

3 Images
3 Images
Gothic
10.0 /10
Released
November 23, 2001

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
t
Powered by

A truly open world doesn’t have to give players free rein right from the start. In fact, the best often use subtle boundaries to guide exploration without making the player feel boxed in. These barriers don’t necessarily have to be invisible walls, but instead natural deterrents like enemies or impossible (for now) terrain that make players curious, not frustrated. The cult classic Gothic handled this masterfully. Step too far into a dangerous area too soon, and the player is likely to get torn apart by monsters.

But that isn't a punishment, but a signal to future greatness. It encouraged players to grow stronger, gain experience, and eventually come back ready to take on the challenge, creating a continuous loop of tension, resistance, and a satisfying payoff. Constraining the player from being able to see all content in one run might also sound counterintuitive to the goal of fun and freedom. However, the exclusivity of in-game factions can serve as meaningful consequences to quest choices or group memberships, as Gothic also demonstrates.

5 An Enticing Plot (With Built-In Excuses To Ignore It) - Morrowind

Letting The Player Set Their Own Pace

The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind
9.3 /10
Released
May 1, 2002

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL

ESRB
T For Teen due to Blood, Violence
Powered by

A gripping main story can elevate any game, but in open-world design, pacing is everything. Players need the freedom to explore, wander, and get sidetracked without feeling like they're betraying the narrative. Morrowind delivers a masterclass in good open-world narrative design. The game sets up its mysterious main quest, points the player in a general direction, and then lets go. The player is encouraged to explore the world, build their character, and engage with factions before returning to the main story when they feel ready to engage with further intrigue.

There’s no sense of urgency unless the player chooses to create it, and that makes the eventual plot payoff (with all its epic high stakes left for the end) feel personal, not forced. When open-world stories let players control the tempo, it becomes a journey on their own terms. In Morrowind, that freedom to drift and return at will is exactly what makes the world so immersive and compelling.

4 Player-Driven Creativity And Customization - Minecraft

From Snapping A Selfie To Reshaping The World

6 Images
6 Images
Minecraft
171
8.9 /10
Released
November 18, 2011

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
E10+ For Everyone 10+ Due To Fantasy Violence
Powered by

Not every open-world game needs to be a full-blown survival sandbox, but the best ones give players room to express themselves, whether it’s through custom outfits, building mechanics, or even just capturing moments in photo mode. With its promise of allowing players to reshape the world with creativity, Minecraft has been one of the most influential games in the last two decades for good reason.

Minecraft 's open-ended sandbox allows players to shape the world block by block, building everything from simple huts to functioning flying machines. But even simpler forms of customization, such as changing a character’s look with a hat or decorating a hideout, help players feel connected to the world.

3 Impactful Progression And Transformation - Kingdom Come: Deliverance

Growth That Feels Earned, Not Handed Over

Kingdom Come: Deliverance
10
7.6 /10
Released
February 13, 2018

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M For Mature 17+ due to Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Nudity, Strong Language, Strong Sexual Content, Use of Alcohol
Powered by

Delivering meaningful progression is hardly an exclusive requirement for open-world games, but without it, the long journey offered by their vast landscapes can feel hollow. Kingdom Come: Deliverance starts the player as a barely competent peasant and slowly shapes them into a capable knight through practice, not handouts or hand-holding. Getting progression right is a delicate balance; too much and rewards feel empty, too little and players will feel the urge to quit.

Many players use achievements as souvenirs to remind them of their time in an open world, but achievements can be represented in-game, too. While simple stat increases may appeal to some, most players crave meaningful changes that reflect their journey, whether perks, loot, or even negative traits like flaws or visible scars.

2 Meaningful Interactivity And Reactivity - Skyrim

From Cultivating Heroic Renown To Plucking Flowers From The Ground

6 Images
6 Images
The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim
9 /10
76
9.4 /10
Released
November 11, 2011

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M For Mature 17+ Due To Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Sexual Themes, Use of Alcohol
Powered by

Open-world games don't necessarily need to include NPCs, but if they do, most players feel that their interactions should leave an impression. Being remembered is important to most people in real life, and the same goes for character in an open world.

Just as important is active interactivity. While being able to catch butterflies and sit at tables may sound trivial compared to slaying dragons or flying at Mach 3 on wingsuits, these small details help make the world real and lived-in. Both NPC reactivity and world interactivity are features that Skyrim excels at, especially the latter.

1 Organic Secrets And Hidden Content - Elden Ring

Forgoing The Checklists And Quest Markers

6 Images
6 Images
Elden Ring
10 /10
65
9.1 /10
Released
February 25, 2022

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Language, Suggestive Themes, Violence
Powered by

Throwing players a massive to-do list in an equally massive open world might ensure that players (achievement hunters especially) will get a long playtime out of an open-world game and eliminate the potential problem of players getting lost and frustrated, but doing so works against the spirit of the genre. Elden Ring 's masterfully designed map and minimal hand-holding prove that organic exploration works best.

When players are told there is a secret nearby via markers (be it treasure or long-forgotten lore), that content is no longer a secret. As anxious as game makers may be to have players find all their hard work, the mark of a truly great open world game is its confidence to keep its juicy secrets hidden for worthy explorers, as Elden Ring does with its illusory walls, hidden questlines, unmarked dungeons, and obscure NPC paths tucked deep in the folds of its world.

item.title: The Most Underrated Resident Evil Games You Need To Play, Ranked
item.description:
Summary

  • Resident Evil Outbreak: File 2: Overlooked classic exploring PS2 online capabilities.
  • Resident Evil: Revelations 2: Co-op fun, better than RE5, great action and gameplay.
  • Resident Evil: The Umbrella Chronicles: Top-tier spinoff exploring beloved characters.

Resident Evil is a name long associated with a long string of incredibly successful titles. This series of games has managed not only one but two successful genre reinventions. It has also spawned a series of movie adaptations that, despite their dubious quality, have never failed to bring in box office gold.

Still, Resident Evil has become such a large brand with so many side games on so many different systems that some great games have ended up overshadowed by the bigger games in the series, like Resident Evil 4 , and other blockbusters from their time that overshadow them. Here's a look at the most overlooked Resident Evil games out there.

7 Resident Evil Outbreak: File 2

A Welcome Upgrade Over A Promising Entry

3 Images
3 Images

Your comment has not been saved

Follow
Followed
Resident Evil Outbreak: File #2
Action
Horror
Systems
Released
September 9, 2004
ESRB
m // Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Strong Language
Developer(s)
Capcom
Publisher(s)
Capcom
Multiplayer
Online Multiplayer

WHERE TO PLAY

PHYSICAL

Powered by

A group of regular people working together online to escape Raccoon City during its worst night seems like an instant classic idea. Unfortunately, the reception to both entries in the Resident Evil Outbreak subseries was tepid at best. It's a shame, because it was one of the first games to truly explore the fun side of the PlayStation 2's online gameplay capabilities.

A similar concept would later end up popularized by Left 4 Dead. It's definitely a much better game than Outbreak File 2 , but the latter definitely deserved way more love than it originally got — especially in Europe, where Outbreak File 2 finally got online gameplay, which was somehow completely absent in the first game.

6 Resident Evil: Revelations 2

Co-Op Done Right

Your comment has not been saved

Follow
Followed
Resident Evil: Revelations 2
Survival Horror
Systems
7 /10
9.0 /10
Released
February 24, 2015
ESRB
M For Mature 17+ due to Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Strong Language
Developer(s)
Capcom
Publisher(s)
Capcom

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

Powered by

Resident Evil 5 almost got a spot on this list. It's a fantastic game, especially when played on co-op, but it's also a mainline entry that sold very well despite negative comparisons to RE4. In an attempt to honor both Resident Evil 5 's memory and another game that deserves it, it's worth discussing Revelations 2.

This game is a true blast of even better co-op action for fans of one of Resident Evil 5's best elements. The plot of Revelations isn't exactly memorable, but the fun players will have turning zombies into Swiss cheese with their friends more than makes up for any perceived shortcoming.

5 Resident Evil: The Umbrella Chronicles

A Top-Tier Spinoff

Resident Evil: The Umbrella Chronicles
Shooter
Systems
Released
November 13, 2007

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
PHYSICAL

ESRB
m // Blood and Gore, Violence
Powered by

What ended up as Resident Evil 3 wasn't originally meant to be a mainline entry, but a spinoff. Luckily, that "promotion" paid off. Resident Evil 6, however — despite its huge production budget — turned out so bad it should have become a spinoff. Resident Evil: Umbrella Chronicles, many say, rightly, should have been the one promoted to mainline entry this time around.

It's a straightforward light gun action title, though one that's extremely fun to play, and it explores a bunch of already beloved characters in the series. Though Umbrella Chronicles doesn't reinvent the wheel like Resident Evil 4 did, it's sure to please the fans of the more action-oriented gameplay introduced by the most successful game in the series.

4 Resident Evil Survivor 2: Code Veronica

A Serious Improvement Over The First Attempt

3 Images
3 Images

Your comment has not been saved

Follow
Followed
Resident Evil Survivor 2 - Code: Veronica
Action
Systems
Released
November 8, 2001
Developer(s)
Namco
Publisher(s)
Capcom
Franchise
Resident Evil

Powered by

The original Resident Evil Survivor definitely won't show up in this list. It's one of the worst games ever made, and likely the worst to ever feature the Resident Evil name. It's an absolute slog that somehow makes using a light gun on the PlayStation less fun than shooting via the controller. It's truly baffling, especially for players experiencing the game in PAL regions, where the game somehow isn't even compatible with light guns.

Survivor 2 , however, improves upon most shortcomings of the original. It also uses the underrated setting of Resident Evil Code Veronica to come up with a much more compelling and fast-paced action scenario.

3 Resident Evil: Dead Aim

One Of The Best Lightgun Shooters Out There

3 Images
3 Images

Your comment has not been saved

Follow
Followed
Resident Evil: Dead Aim
Shooter
Systems
Released
June 17, 2003
ESRB
m // Blood and Gore, Violence
Developer(s)
Capcom Production Studio 3
Publisher(s)
Capcom
Franchise
Resident Evil

WHERE TO PLAY

PHYSICAL

Powered by

If there's one thing RE purists complain about when it comes to Resident Evil 4 , it's the clear switch from survival horror to full-on action horror, roundhouse kicks, suplexes, and all. The problem with that argument is that RE4 is amazing and proved an essential step forward for the franchise. Gamers would know that if they had played Resident Evil: Dead Aim , a pretty good RE title that didn't pull off the move to action territory as well as Resident Evil 4 did.

It plays as a regular third-person action game that switches to first-person Lightgun action when the player approaches the zombies. The transition might be a bit jarring at first, but it's a fun game, nonetheless. Even those who don't vibe with it will at least see it as an important stepping stone into what would later become Resident Evil 4.

2 Resident Evil 0

An Interesting Twist On The Formula

3 Images
3 Images

Your comment has not been saved

Follow
Followed
Resident Evil 0
Survival Horror
Systems
8.7 /10
Released
November 12, 2002
ESRB
M For Mature 17+ Due To Intense Violence, Blood and Gore
Developer(s)
Capcom
Publisher(s)
Capcom

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

Powered by

Before Resident Evil 5 nailed the campaign by allowing players to do it in full co-op mode, there was Resident Evil 0, which had one player controlling two different characters in a way that made it feel like a co-op game. It was a bit more confusing than it should have been, as was the more punishing inventory system that required players to drop stuff to pick up later or to abandon altogether.

However, there was a lot of good in it, as well. It was a fresh take on the series that still kept those beautiful 3D environments from REmake. Starring Rebecca Chambers and a mysterious co-main character nobody knew anything about, the story was filled to the brim with stakes. Though 0 isn't perfect, the only reason it didn't garner a more dedicated fanbase was that it was stranded on the excellent but unsuccessful GameCube for too long.

1 Resident Evil Remake

One Of The Finest Resident Evil Experiences To Date

6 Images
6 Images

Your comment has not been saved

Follow
Followed
Resident Evil
Survival Horror
Systems
8.5 /10
Released
April 30, 2002
ESRB
Mature 17+ // Blood and Gore, Violence
Developer(s)
Capcom Production Studio 4
Publisher(s)
Capcom
Franchise
Resident Evil
Number of Players
1

Powered by

Nowadays, gamers get showered with fake trailers whenever there's a new gaming event coming out. Back in 2001, when Nintendo rolled out the first trailer for " REmake" , fake trailers still weren't a thing, but this game just looked too good to be true. It showed a never-before-seen combination between pre-rendered backgrounds and the GameCube's fantastic 3D that had to be played to be believed. Then, the game came out, and it was the most horrifyingly beautiful thing anyone had seen up until then.

The game itself improves upon the original in every single way, and it got great reviews, but it was stuck on the unsuccessful GameCube for too long to snowball into something huge. A few years later, fans got Resident Evil 4 , which killed the interest in horror games with pre-rendered backgrounds, so the original REmake remains the swansong of that particular genre of horror. Even years later, and especially because of the HD remaster that further improves the game, REmake remains one of the best Resident Evil titles out there.

item.title: Ready or Not: Release Time and Date (Consoles)
item.description:
Ready or Not is a tactical shooter that draws inspiration from classic games like SWAT and the Rainbow Six series. It offers a more strategic alternative to fast-paced shooters by placing players in tense, realistic scenarios as members of a SWAT team. Success in the game relies heavily on teamwork and making the right decisions during missions.

It began its journey as an Early Access title on Steam, where it was available for two years before its full PC launch in December 2023. Ready or Not is set to be released on PlayStation 5 and Xbox Series X/S on July 15, 2025 . However, releases are scheduled for different times depending on the region. For those wondering when they can get their hands on this title, here are the exact release times and dates for the console versions of Ready or Not.

What Time Does Ready On Not Launch On Consoles?

The console versions of Ready or Not launches on July 15, 2025, but unlike some titles that have a global midnight launch in their specific territory, this game will release simultaneously, which means it will drop at different times in different regions.

For Steam Deck users who don't mind slightly smaller text, Ready or Not is marked as "playable" on the Steam Store. The developers at Void Interactive have enhanced controller support as they transitioned towards consoles, which allows the game to run smoothly on the Steam Deck as well. Moreover, it runs surprisingly well out of the box on medium settings, with only minor adjustments being required to maintain optimal performance.

Ready Or Not: Deluxe Edition, Explained

Unfortunately, the Deluxe Edition of Ready or Not does not provide early access to the game on consoles. However, it does include significant content that fans may be interested in. The edition features three DLC packs that were previously released on PC. The DLC packs include:

Home Invasion

This pack features missions set after a Category 5 hurricane that has led to widespread home invasions and looting. It includes three missions, new weapons and equipment.

Dark Waters

This pack takes players to a yacht, an oil rig, and an abandoned island resort, offering a total of six new missions, along with new equipment and guns. Additionally, there is a third DLC pack scheduled for release sometime in 2026.
